When we talk about differentiating related functions, we're essentially looking at two functions that are connected in some way, and we want to understand how changes in one function affect the other.
For example, let's consider two related functions: position and velocity. Imagine you have a car moving along a straight road. The position function tells you where the car is at any given time, and the velocity function tells you how fast the car is moving.

Main hardware components:

CPU
Control Unit: retrieves and decodes instructions. Coordinates activities on computer

Secondary memory: non-volatile. Data is stored even if computer is turned off
Input devices: sends info from outside to the computer
Output devices: sends info from computer to the outside
Programs are instructions that tell the computer to do a task. Algorithms are set of well-defined steps
Machine language instructions are binary numbers that tell the computer to do something. Instead of writing just 1's and 0's, programmers use programming languages
Programming languages can be either low-level or high-level. Lower level languages are closer to the machine language. Higher-level languages are closer to human language.
To translate from high-level program to executable:

Create program
Run preprocessor to convert source file to source code
Run compiler to convert source program code to machine instructions
Run linker to connect hardware-specific code to machine instructions. Creates executable file
IDEs are tools used to write, compile, and debug programs all in one place.
Programming langauge elements

Key words: words with special meaning in C++. Examples include using, int, return
Programmer-defined identifiers: names made by programmer. It can be used to represent variables, functions, etc.
Operators: performs operations on data
Punctuation: marks end of statement or separates items in a list
Syntax: how program should be written
Variable: holds data
To declare (make) a variable:
double hours; // You can declare multiple in one line too! double rate, pay; Copy
Programming process

Define what program will do
Visualize it running on the coputer
Use design tools to create a model of the program
Check model for logical errors
Type code. Compile it.
Correct any errors.
Run program with test data
Correct any errors. Repeat steps 5-8 as many times as necessary
Validate results
Procedural programming: focuses on process. Procedures/functions are written to process data
Object-oriented programming: focuses on data and ways to manipulate it

item.title: 02 Intro to C++
item.description:
Related:
Last modified: 2024-01-20 16:01:41


[TOC]

Special characters you should know:

The preprocessor reads the program before it is compiled. Any lines beginning in # will be executed first.
Multi-line comments
/* Multi-line comment begins here. Add anything in between. And ends here. */ Copy
Namespaces organize the names of program entities.
// Grabs the namespace called "std". using namespace std; Copy
Functions are used to group several statements together.
// Note that the data type of what the function returns must be stated too int main() { cout << "This is inside a function!\n"; cout << "You can put in multiple lines and do multiple things inside one function!" return 0; } Copy

Warning This section uses strings. Please include #include <string> at the beginning of your program to use strings.
cout is an object that displays output on the computer screen. For instance
// To use cout, you need to have these 3 lines: #include <iostream> #include <string> using namespace std; // cout must also be inside a function too int main() { cout << "Hello world!"; } Copy
would display Hello world! on the screen.
You can also send more than one item to cout too.
#include <iostream> #include <string> using namespace std; // cout must also be inside a function too int main() { cout << "Hello" << "world"; // Or, you could do this too cout << "Hello "; cout << "world"; } Copy
cout only outputs one line to the screen. To create a new line use endl or add \n in a string
#include <iostream> #include <string> using namespace std; int main() { cout << "Hello" << endl; cout << "world" << endl; /* Outputs: Hello world */ // You can use \n too cout << "Hello\n"; cout << "world"; /* Outputs: Hello world */ } Copy
You can even print with variables.
#include <iostream> #include <string> using namespace std; int main() { int number = 5; cout << "Number: " << number; } Copy

#include inserts the contents of another file into the program. It is a preprocessor, so it's not part of C++. Do not put a ;.
For example, if you put in
#include <iostream> Copy
You are telling C++ to get a header file called iostream (which allows you to display stuff on the screen via cout).

Variables store stuff. They need a name and a type of data to hold. They also must be defined before they are used.
Here's an example:
int item; Copy
Literals are values written into the code. For instance "hello world" is a string literal and 12 could be an integer literal.

Identifiers is a programmer-defined name for some part of a program. Includes variables, functions, and more! These names should represent what the variable, function, or whatever does.
Naming rules for identifiers:

First character must be a letter or an underscore
Use distinct names
No special characters
Key words are reserved words in C++ that cannot used as identifiers.

Variables of the same type can be defined on the same lines, if you want.
int length, width; int length; int width; // Both do the same thing. Copy
To assign variables, use the equals sign or enclose it in parentheses
int width; width = 12; // Assigns 12 to width // You can also initialize (assign a value when the variable is defined) int length = 12; // You can initialize multiple on one line too int depth = 13, height = 2, area; // Parentheses method int num(5); int num{5}; // in C++ 11 or higher. This will check if `5` is an int or not. Copy

There are two different types of numbers: integers and floats.
ints store whole numbers. But, you can make them store other numbers too.
// all the different integer types. int num; short num; long num; long long num; Copy
Numbers are stored as ints by default, if they are whole numbers. You can change this by appending L to the number. This might arise if you've defined a variable as something other than an int and you assign it an integer.
int num; num = 8; // You can also choose to store them as "long" by appending L num = 8L; // Or, store as "long long" with LL num = 8LL; // Constants that begin with '0' are base 8 num = 075 // Constants that begin wtih '0x' are base 16 num = 0x75AB Copy
Integers can also be unsigned. This means they can only store positive values. To do this, add unsigned before the data type.

Floating points can hold decimals as well as whole numbers. They are all stored in a form similar to scientific notation and are signed too.
There are 3 types: float, double, and long double.

long double is as big as or bigger than double; double is as big as or bigger than float.
float number; number = 31.4; // You can also use E notation too number = 3.14E1; number = 3.14e1; // You can also force numbers to be a long double or float too number = 31.4f // float number = 31.4L // long double Copy
Warning If you're trying to assign a float to an int variable, the fractional part will be discarded.

Holds a single character or integer. They must be enclosed in single quotation marks (').
char letter; letter = 'C'; // Warning! This will not work! letter = "C"; Copy
Strings also hold characters. They must be enclosed with "". You also need to put #include <string> too.
#include <string> // Required if you want to use strings // Define string with "string" string name; name = "Bob"; Copy
When strings are stored in a computer's memory, they have \0 appended to them. The \0 is called the "null terminator" and it signifies the end of a string.

Booleans are either true or false. To use them in C++, use bool.
bool finished; finished = false; Copy

sizeof() tells you how big a data type or variable is.
double price; cout << "Memory size: " << sizeof(price) cout << "Double size: " << sizeof(double) Copy

auto tells the compiler to determine the variable's data type automatically based on the initialization value. It works for all data types.
auto price = 30; // Turns into an int auto letter = 'D'; // Turns into a char Copy

Named constant (aka "constant variable") has data that cannot be changed during execution. They are usually written in uppercase letters.
const char GREETING = 'Hello'; Copy

Scope: part of program where a variable can be accessed. Variables can't be used before they are defined.


A special note on division. If you divide two integers, you get back an integer. This can be problematic because there are situations where dividing two integers and gives a float instead. For example, you might . But, in C++, would equal if both terms were integers. To solve this, make one of the numbers into a float.
Here's a program to show you the differences:
#include <iostream> #include <string> using namespace std; int main() { cout << "This is what 5/2 looks like when you:" << endl; cout << "\tDivide by two integers: " << 5 / 2 << endl; cout << "\tDivide by at least one float: " << 5 / 2.0; return 0; } Copy

item.description:
Related:
Last modified: 2024-06-01 18:14:14


[TOC]

The cin object reads input from the keyboard. It requires #include <iostream> to work.
Here's what it looks like:
#include <iostream> using namespace std; int main() { int age; // `cout` asks the user a question. `cin` reads the user's input and // automatically formats it to fit the variable. cout << "Age: "; cin >> age; cout << endl; // `cin` can even ask for more than one variable at a time. float height, width, area; cout << "Enter 2 floats for the height and width. Press enter after each one.\n"; cin >> height >> width; cout << "Height: " << height; // cin >> height; cout << "Width: " << width; // cin >> width; area = height * width; cout << "Area: " << area; } Copy

Math can be done as a variable, cout, or other statements.
All math in C++ follows the Order of Operations.
Here's how to do common math expressions:
#include <iostream> #include <string> #include <cmath> // Required for exponents. using namespace std; int main() { int a = 5; int b = 3; cout << "A: " << a << endl; cout << "B: " << b << endl; cout << "Addition: " << a + b << endl; cout << "Subtraction: " << a - b << endl; cout << "Multiplication: " << a * b << endl; // static_cast<float>(a) sets `a` to a float cout << "Division (with floats): " << static_cast<float>(a) / b << endl; cout << "Modulus: " << a % b << endl; // Exponents require #include <cmath> cout << "Exponents (A^B): " << pow (a, b); } Copy

Hierarchy of number types in C++ (ranked by highest number they can hold; higher numbers first):

long double
double
float
unsigned long
long
unsigned int
int
Type coercion: automatically converting one operand to another data type

Promotion: converting the operand to a higher data type
Demotion: converting the operand to a lower data type
Rules of coercion:

char, short, unsigned short are automatically promoted to int
When operating on values of different data types, the lower one is promoted to the type of the higher one.
When using the = operator, the expression on the right will be converted to the left expression's type

Variables can only store a set range of values. If a number goes outside this range, the number "wraps" around. For example, if the maximum value is 1000 and the minimum is 0 and you get a value like -1, it will "wrap around" and give you 1000.
Overflow vs. underflow:

Overflow is when the assigned value is too big
Underflow is when the assigned value is too small

Type casting manually changes a data's type. This can be useful, especially when dividing.
#include <iostream> using namespace std; int main() { int pay = 10; int hours_worked = 4; // This will give you the correct answer: 2.5 cout << "Hourly Wage: " << static_cast<float>(pay) / hours_worked << endl; // Other methods. static_cast is still preferred cout << float(pay) / hours_worked << endl; cout << (float)pay / hours_worked << endl; // Bear in mind though that this will give you 2.0. It divides to give 2, then turns 2 into a float cout << static_cast<float>(pay / hours_worked) } Copy

You can assign multiple variables to one variable.
#include <iostream> // Makes x, y, and z equal 5 x = y = z = 5; cout << x << endl; cout << y << endl; cout << z << endl; Copy
Combined assignment is where you take a variable and perform some operation with another number to itself. Usually, they look like this:
#include <iostream> int main () { int x = 5; // Adding 4 to x x = x + 4; x += 4; cout << x; // Subtracts 3 from x x = x - 3; x -= 3; // Multiply x by 10 x = x * 10; x *= 10; // Divide x by 5 x = x / 5; x /= 5; // Finds remainder after dividing x by 7 x = x % 7; x %= 7; } Copy

The iomanip header file helps you control how data is outputted. For example, you can use it to output only a certain number of decimal points.

setw() lets you set a fixed minimum number of characters for your output. This is useful if you want to make tables.
For example, this program
#include <iomanip> // Required for setw() #include <iostream> // Required for displaying output int main () { int value = 42; cout << "[" << setw(5) << value << "]"; } Copy
outputs
[ 42] Copy
Notice that there are 3 spaces between [ and 42. This is because 42 only has 2 characters and requires 3 spaces for it to have 5 characters in total.
If the value in setw() is less than the output, no spaces will be outputted.
For example, this program
#include <iomanip> #include <iostream> int main () { int value = 12345; cout << "[" << setw(3) << value << "]"; } Copy
outputs
[12345] Copy

setprecision() rounds your output to a certain number of significant figures.
#include <iostream> #include <iomanip> using namespace std; int main () { float pi = 3.14159265 cout << setprecision(5) << pi << endl; cout << setprecision(4) << pi << endl; cout << setprecision(3) << pi << endl; cout << setprecision(2) << pi << endl; cout << setprecision(1) << pi << endl; } Copy
outputs
3.1416 3.142 3.14 3.1 3 Copy
It's important to note that setprecision(x) outputs x-1 significant figures.

fixed forces cout to print a certain number of digits.

showpoint shows trailing zeroes if there aren't enough significat figures in the decimal

The problem with using cin is that it ignores things like spaces and tabs. To fix this, use getline(). It reads an entire line of input.
#include <iostream> #include <string> using namespace std; int main() { string name; string city; // Now you can input your first and last name. cout << "Name: "; getline(cin, name); // You can input city names with spaces cout << "\nCity: "; getline(cin, city); cout << endl; cout << name << endl; cout << city; } Copy
cin.get() will read the next character. This is useful if you want to make a program say "Enter a key to continue."
#include <iostream> using namespace std; char ch; cout << "Strike any key to continue"; cin >> ch; // cin can also be set to ignore characters cin.ignore(); // ignore next character int x = 3; cin.ignore(x, '\n'); // ignore `x` number of characters or until a '\n' is received Copy
Strings
// Find length of string string state = "Texas"; int size = state.length(); // Concatenation string city = "Austin"; string country = "USA"; string location = city + state; string location += country; Copy
setw() sets the width for output. It will add additional spaces if your variable doesn't have enough characters. If there are too many, it will cut some off.
cin.ignore() ignores the next character that is pressed. cin.ignore(x) ignores the next x characters that are pressed.

cmath is a library that helps you do math. Use #include <cmath> to use it.
#include <iostream> #include <cmath> int main() { // Calculate square root double num = 25.0; double sqrtResult = std::sqrt(num); std::cout << "Square root of " << num << " is: " << sqrtResult << std::endl; // Calculate sine double angleInDegrees = 45.0; double angleInRadians = angleInDegrees * M_PI / 180.0; // Convert degrees to radians double sineResult = std::sin(angleInRadians); std::cout << "Sine of " << angleInDegrees << " degrees is: " << sineResult << std::endl; // Calculate logarithm double logValue = 100.0; double logResult = std::log10(logValue); std::cout << "Logarithm base 10 of " << logValue << " is: " << logResult << std::endl; return 0; } Copy
<cstdlib> contains functions for random numbers and <ctime> contains functions for time.

Act like you're a computer executing the program. Take things step-by-step. This is useful for finding errors.

item.description:

Last modified: 2024-01-28 12:30:40


[TOC]
In C++, if statements are written like this:
#include <string> #include <iostream> using namespace std; int number = 80; int minimum; if (number > minimum) { cout << "You have more than the minimum"; } else if (number < minimum) { cout << "You do not meet the minimum requirement."; } else if (number == minimum) { cout << "You have the same amount as the minimum"; } else { cout << "Enter a valid number."; } // If the if statement only spans one line, you don't have to use curly braces if (number > 0) cout << "Number is greater than zero." Copy
If statements can be shortened using conditional operators. The basic format is
test_expression ? run_if_true : run_if_false Copy
For example, the if statement and conditional operator below are equivalent.
#include <string> #include <iostream> using namespace std; int number = 3; if (number > 0) cout << "Positive."; else cout << "Negative."; number > 0 ? cout << "Positive." : cout << "Negative." Copy
Basic logic (ordered by precedence).

! gives you NOT logic. Reverse boolean value. True becomes False and vice versa
&& gives you AND logic. Both conditions must be true.
|| gives you OR logic. Either condition can be true.
char and string type variables can be compared based on the total ASCII values that each character has. For example, if you have a string called "Mark", C++ will add up each character's value on the ASCII table.
Flags signal if a condition exists.

If it equals 0, it is false. This tells us that something is missing.
All other values output true. This tells us that something exists there.
switch can also be used instead of if/else if. switch compares the expression inside its parentheses with the list of cases that it has. If no matching value is found, it uses default.
If a value is the same, it executes the code inside the case block. It will continue running this until it runs into break. If no break is found at the end of a case block, it will move onto the next until it finds break.
break is used to exit the switch statement.
#include <iostream> int main() { char grade; std::cout << "Enter your grade (A, B, C, D, or F): "; std::cin >> grade; switch (grade) { case 'A': std::cout << "Excellent! Keep up the good work."; break; case 'B': std::cout << "Good job! You're doing well."; break; case 'C': std::cout << "Not bad. Room for improvement."; break; case 'D': std::cout << "You need to work harder."; break; case 'F': std::cout << "Uh-oh, you failed. Time to study more."; break; default: // Optional, but recommended. std::cout << "Invalid grade entered."; } return 0; } Copy
switch is best for menu-driven programs. Menu-driven programs

display a menu
get the user's input
use the input as an expression in switch
compare the expression to all case blocks
Scope

variables inside { } have a local or block scope
when inside a block of another block, you can define variables of the same name as the outer block
the outer definition is not available whilst inside the inner block
not a good idea

item.title: 05 Loops - COP 2220
item.description:
Related:
Last modified: 2024-02-09 19:08:17


[TOC]

++ increments by one. In other words, it adds 1.
-- decrements by one. In other words, it subtracts 1.
#include <iostream> int main () { int val = 0; // All of the following add 1 to `val`. val = val + 1; val += 1; val++; ++val; // All of the following subtract 1 from `val`. val = val - 1; val -= 1; val--; --val; cout << val; } Copy
In prefix mode (example: --val, ++val), the variable is incremented then returned.
In postfix mode (example: val--, val++), the variable is returned then incremented.
This can have an impact on your program!
Increments

may be used in expressions (i.e. ++num + val--;)
must have some location in memory
can be used in relational expressions (i.e. ++num < val)

Loops repeatedly run a section of code.
While loops execute a section of statements until the expression is false.
while (expression) { statement; } Copy
Be careful of creating infinite loops. It can crash your system.
While loops can be used for input validation. This is because they execute the same lines of code until the user inputs a valid choice (which makes the expression false).
Counter: variable that is incremented or decremented every time the loop executes code.

do-while: execute the loop, then test the expression.
do { statement; } while (expression); Copy
do-while executes the statement at least once. This also makes them good for menu-driven programs.

for(initialization; test; update) { statement; } Copy

initialization assigns a variable to something. You can initialize multiple if you wish. Separate them using a ,.
example: for(x=1, y=1; test; update)
may be omitted. Just add a ;.
example: for(; x<5; x++)
test tests an expression.
If it's true, it will execute the loop again.
If false, break out of the loop
update: executed if test is true. You can update multiple variables if you want
example: for(x=1; x<5; x++, y++)
Use for loops when there is:

an initialization
a false condition to stop the loop
an update to occur at the end of each iteration

Sentinels terminate input. This is useful when you don't know how many values the user to input but you still want a way for the program to quit.

Nested loops are when loops are inside other loops.

To store files using your program:

Open the file
Use the file
Close the file
#include <fstream> is used for file access.

ifstream accepts input
ofstream outputs to file
fstream does input and output
To define file stream objects
#include <fstream> #include <iostream> #include <string> // Defining file stream objects ifstream input_file; ofstream output_file; fstream file; // Open files input_file.open("input.txt"); output_file.open("output.txt"); file.open("input_and_output.txt"); // Sending output to a file output_file << "Sending output to a file"; // Sending file input to variables string input, string input_2, string input_3; input_file >> input; // You can even copy input to multiple variables input_file >> input_2 >> input_3; /* - If file input was accepted successfully, `>>` will output true. - If file input was not accepted successfully, `>>` will output false This is useful for error handling. */ // Close files when you're finished. input_file.close(); output_file.close(); file.close(); Copy

break lets you break out of a loop. Use it sparingly because it makes code harder to read.
continue jumps straight to the end of the loop and prepares for the next iteration. It skips the rest of the code. Just like break, use it sparingly because it makes code hard to read.

item.title: 06 Functions - COP 2220
item.description:
Related:
Last modified: 2024-02-29 14:49:10


[TOC]
Modular programming: break up a program into many smaller functions.

easy to maintain
easy to write
Functions: collection of statements used to perform a task.

Function call: statement that causes function to execute
Function definition: statements inside a function. Requires

return type
name of function
parameter list
body
To define a function in C++:
#include <iostream> // If you don't want to return anything, use `void` void function (parameters) { cout << "Currently inside another function."; } // This function is called `main` // It returns an `int` // `int main` is a function header int main (parameters) { int num = 3; return num; } Copy
Remember to define it before main().
Calling a function:
int function () { int num = 2; return num; } function(); Copy

Lets the compiler know about a function before calling the function.
It's best to place prototypes near the beginning of the file.
Prototypes require the return type of the function, the function name, and any parameters the function has.
#include <iostream> using namespace std; // Function prototypes. This lets compiler know that `function` exists. void function(); int main () { cout << "Calling the first function" << endl; function(); // Calling `function` } void function () { cout << "Function has been called" << endl; } Copy
These are ideal if you defined a function below main().

Arguments send data into a function when it is called. Arguments are sometimes called "actual parameter" or "actual argument".
The variables that hold this data for a function are called parameters. Parameters are sometimes called "formal parameter" or "formal argument."
int main () { // 2 and 3 are passed in as arguments. multiply(2, 3); } int multiply (int a, int b) { // a and b are "parameters" return a * b } Copy
Prototypes must declare the data type of a parameter.
void prototype(int); // For multiple arguments void prototype(int, char, string); Copy

Pass by value: when arguments are passed into a function, values are copied into its parameter.
Example:
#include <iostream> using namespace std; // Prototype of even_or_odd int even_or_odd(int) int main () { int val = 3; // val is passed in as an argument even_or_odd(val); } int even_or_odd(int num) { // num is an parameter. even_or_odd can change num, but not val return num % 2; } Copy

return can end the execution of a function if nothing is listed. Any lines of code after return are not executed.
#include <iostream> using namespace std; int main () { cout << "Hello!" << endl; return; // Stops the function here cout << "This will not be displayed because it's below the return line"; } Copy
return can also output whatever is ordered to. Additionally, the result of a function can be assigned to a variable.
#include <iostream> using namespace std; int main () { int num_1 = 3; int num_2 = 2; sum = add(num_1, num_2); cout << sum; } int sum (int val_1, int val_2) { // Outputs the sum of val_1 and val_2 return val_1 + val_2; } Copy
Booleans can be returned too. Just make sure the function outputs true or false.

Variables defined inside a function are local to that function. They stay inside the function.
This means functions can share variable names and not have any problems.
The "lifetime" of a variable is the part of code where a variable exists.
Global variables can be accessed by all functions. Their scope is the start of when they are defined all the way until a program ends.

Heavily discouraged because it makes debugging hard
Globals should ideally be global constants (meaning, their values don't change)
Automatically initialize to 0 or NULL.
Local variables are not automatically initialized. They must be manually initialized.
Define them outside of functions.
#include <iostream> // Global constants const int GLOBAL = 34; int main () { std::cout << GLOBAL * 3; } Copy

Normally, when functions terminates, the contents of a variable are deleted.
static local variables retain their contents between function calls. They are defined and initialized when the function is first called. They keep this value once the function ends.

Cannot be called in other functions
0 is the default initialization value
When contents are retained between function calls, we say they "persist."
#include <iostream> void incrementAndPrint() { // Static local variable persists between function calls static int count = 0; // Increment the static local variable count++; // Print the value of the static local variable std::cout << "Count is: " << count << std::endl; } int main() { // Call the function multiple times incrementAndPrint(); // Output: Count is: 1 incrementAndPrint(); // Output: Count is: 2 incrementAndPrint(); // Output: Count is: 3 return 0; } Copy

Default arguments are values assigned to a parameter automatically if none are specified.
Default arguments can be declared in prototypes or inside the function header.
Here's an example of default arguments in a function header.
#include <iostream> using namespace std; // Function with default arguments void greet(string name = "Guest", string greeting = "Hello") { cout << greeting << ", " << name << "!" << endl; } int main() { // Calling the function without any arguments greet(); // Output: Hello, Guest! // Calling the function with one argument greet("Alice"); // Output: Hello, Alice! // Calling the function with both arguments greet("Bob", "Good morning"); // Output: Good morning, Bob! return 0; } Copy
If greet() doesn't have any arguments passed in, it will use string name = "Guest" and string greeting = "Hello" as its default parameters.
And another example where the default arguments are in the prototype.
#include <iostream> using namespace std; // Function prototype with default arguments void greet(string name = "Guest", string greeting = "Hello"); int main() { // Calling the function without any arguments greet(); // Output: Hello, Guest! // Calling the function with one argument greet("Alice"); // Output: Hello, Alice! // Calling the function with both arguments greet("Bob", "Good morning"); // Output: Good morning, Bob! return 0; } // Function definition with default arguments void greet(string name, string greeting) { cout << greeting << ", " << name << "!" << endl; } Copy
Default arguments come with some rules.

Define default arguments last.
If an argument is omitted, all other arguments after must be omitted too.
// Define default arguments last! void greet(string greeting, string name = "Guest"); // OK void greet(string name = "Guest", string greeting); // NOT OK // Arguments after omitted argument must be gone too greet("Hello", "User", "1234"); // OK greet("Hello", , "1234"); // NOT OK Copy

Reference variables are an alias for another variable. They are defined with an ampersand (&). Once defined, you no longer need to include an &.
Once a reference variable is initialized, they cannot be changed to refer to another variable. They always refer to the variable they were initialized with.
You can use it just like the original variable. Any changes made to the reference variable will affect the original variable, and vice versa.
#include <iostream> int main () { int y = 20; int &ref_y = y; // Reference variable referring to y ref_y = 30; // This changes the value of y to 30 std::cout << y; // Output will be 30 } Copy
Reference variables are often used in function parameters to allow functions to modify the values of variables outside the function's scope without making a copy of the variable. This makes functions more efficient.

Remember, pass by copies the variable and stores it as a function parameter.
For example:
#include <iostream> using namespace std; void increment(int &num) { // Notice how we don't need to return num too num++; } int main() { int z = 5; increment(z); // z will be modified to 6. cout << z; // Output will be 6 return 0; } Copy
If you wanted that same output using pass by, you would have to do this instead:
#include <iostream> using namespace std; int increment(int num) { num++; // Increment the local copy of num return num; } int main() { int z = 5; y = increment(z); // z will remain unchanged because pass-by-value creates a copy cout << z; // Output will be 5 cout << y; // Output will be 6 return 0; } Copy

Function overloading in C++ refers to the ability to define multiple functions with the same name but with different parameter lists. These functions can have the same name but perform different tasks based on the number or types of parameters they accept.
This is helpful if you have a function that needs to do different things based on the input parameters, but you still want them to share a name.

Here's an example program where you can calculate the area of different shapes.
#include <iostream> using namespace std; // Function to calculate the area of a square double calculateArea(double sideLength) { return sideLength * sideLength; } // Function to calculate the area of a rectangle double calculateArea(double length, double width) { return length * width; } int main() { cout << "Area of square with side length 5: " << calculateArea(5.0) << endl; cout << "Area of rectangle with length 4 and width 6: " << calculateArea(4.0, 6.0) << endl; return 0; } Copy
As you can see, calculateArea can calculate the area of a square and a rectangle depending on how many parameters you give it.

If you give it one double, it will give you the area of a square.
If you give it two doubles, it will give you the area of a rectangle.

Here's another example where the type of data you give affects the function used:
#include <iostream> #include <string> using namespace std; // Overloaded function to display a string void displayMessage(string message) { cout << "Message: " << message << endl; } // Overloaded function to display a character void displayMessage(char character) { cout << "Character: " << character << endl; } // Overloaded function to display an integer void displayMessage(int number) { cout << "Number: " << number << endl; } int main() { displayMessage("Hello, world!"); // Displays a message displayMessage('A'); // Displays a character displayMessage(123); // Displays a number return 0; } Copy
displayMessage is able to adapt to different types of data and output whatever is needed.

Inputting a string outputs Message:
Inputting a char outputs Character:
Inputting an int outputs Number:

exit() terminates the program. You can also pass an int to tell the user what caused the program to exit.
Typically, exit() is used if the program ends for a weird reason.
exit() requires cstdlib header file (put #include <cstdlib> at the beginning).
Examples
exit(0); exit(EXIT_SUCCESS); // Indicates successful exit exit(EXIT_FAILURE); // Indicates failed exit Copy

Stubs and drivers are useful for testing and debugging functions.

Stub: a dummy function used in place of another. It displays a message indicating that the function was called as well as parameters
Driver: a function that tests another function by calling it. It can pass in arguments and test return values.

item.title: 07 Arrays and Vectors
item.description:
Related:
Last modified: 2024-02-29 14:55:24


[TOC]

Arrays can hold multiple values. They are declared using []. It will also allocate the appropriate number of memory slots for the variable.
Arrays must have a declared type.
int numbers[5]; // Allocates 5 memory slots for numbers Copy
The memory size of an array is (number of elements) * (size of each element).
In the example above, numbers would take up 20 bytes because 5 items with 4 bytes each gives you 20.
Size declarators are constants that set the size of an array. They make the maintenance of a program easier in the future.
const int SIZE = 5; int array[SIZE]; Copy

Every element of an array has a subscript. The subscript tells you where an element is in an array.
Subscripts start at 0. To access the first item, use array[0] where array is the name of the array.
This also means the last element is elements away (where is the number of elements in a list).
Elements in an array can be used just like variables. However, to use an array, you must access its elements.
#include <iostream> int array[5]; array[0] = 0; array[1] = 2; // This will work std::cout << array[1]; // This will not work std::cout << array; Copy
By default,

global array elements are initialized to 0.
local array elements are uninitialized
You can also initialize arrays with an initialization list (things you want to assign to an array as soon as it's defined). The number of elements in an initialization list must be less than or equal to the number of elements in the array.
// Array is initialized with the // initialization list of {0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5} int array[5] = {0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5}; // This will not work. invalid doesn't have enough space int invalid[2] = {0, 1, 2}; // This will assign the first 3 values and set the rest to 0 int unassigned[5] = {0, 1, 2}; Copy
Array sizes can be implicitly determined by the size of an initialization list.
// implicitSize will have an implicit size of 6 because it's given 6 items. int implicitSize[] = {0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5} Copy
char type arrays can have strings passed into them. They are the only type of array that allows you to not use {}.
char name[20] = "Bob"; Copy
However, I discourage using char arrays. It's better to work with strings instead.
Warning When using arrays, C++ does not check if the subscript you use is within its range. You can use subscripts outside of an array's range, but doing so may cause issues in your program.
Here's an example of C++ not checking outside its range.
outOfBounds[2] = {0, 0, 0, 0, 0} Copy
outOfBounds is only given 2 spaces in memory, but it has to store 5 items. So, to fix this, the program will overwrite memory spaces that may be used for other purposes. This will likely cause issues in the program.

Range-based for loops allow you to loop over all elements in an array. This decreases the likelihood of going out of bounds.
The general syntax is
for (dataType rangeVariable : array) statement; Copy
Here's an example:
#include <iostream> using namespace std; int main () { int numbers[5] = {10, 20, 30, 40, 50}; for (int &i : numbers) { i++; // Adds one to each element in the list. cout << i << endl; } } Copy

To copy one array to another:
int newArray[3] int array[3] = {0, 1, 2}; // Don't do this newArray = array; // Do this instead for (int i : array) newArray[i] = array[i]; Copy
If you don't know how big an array will be, make the array large enough to hold the largest expected number of elements. Additionally, track how many items are in that array.

Parallel arrays are two or more arrays that contain related information to one another. Typically, they're related by their subscripts.
In this example, studentNames correspond with studentScores.
#include <iostream> #include <string> using namespace std; int main() { const int SIZE = 5; // Arrays to store student names and their corresponding scores string studentNames[SIZE] = {"Alice", "Bob", "Charlie", "David", "Eve"}; int studentScores[SIZE] = {85, 90, 75, 88, 92}; // Displaying the student names and scores cout << "Student Names and Scores:" << endl; for (int i = 0; i < SIZE; ++i) { cout << studentNames[i] << ": " << studentScores[i] << endl; } return 0; } Copy

To pass an array to a function, just use the array name:
void showScores (scores[]) { for (int score : scores) { cout << score << "\t"; } } int tests[3] = {80, 90, 100}; showScores(tests); Copy
To define a function that takes an array parameter, use an empty [] for array argument:
// function prototype void showScores(int []); // function header void showScores(int tests[]) { ; } Copy
It's common for you to also pass in the array size as an argument. This lets the function know how big to make the array.
Arrays in functions are like reference variables. Any changes made to an array inside a function are also reflected outside the function.

Arrays can have multiple sets inside them.
const int ROWS = 3, COLS = 5; // Create an array with 3 rows and 5 columns int table[ROWS][COLS]; // To access anything inside table, you need to use 2 subscripts table[1][2]; // You can also access an array of data by just accessing one subscript table[1]; // You can even specify a third dimension int third_dimension = [ROWS][COLS][3]; // Like normal arrays, you can leave [] empty for a non-specific number of elements in an array int anyLength = [][][]; Copy
Use nested for loops to loop over elements of the inner array.

STL vectors, also known as C++ vectors, are dynamic arrays provided by the Standard Template Library (STL) in C++. They are a sequence container that encapsulates dynamic arrays.
Unlike built-in arrays, which have a fixed size, vectors can resize themselves automatically when needed.
To use, make sure you have #include <vector> in your code.
This code snippet tells you more about what vector can do.
#include <iostream> #include <vector> using namespace std; int main() { // Declare a vector to hold int elements vector<int> scores; // Declare a vector with initial size 30 vector<int> scoresSize30(30); // Declare a vector and initialize all elements to 0 vector<int> scoresInitialized(30, 0); // Declare a vector initialized to size and contents of another vector vector<int> finals(scoresInitialized); // Initialize a vector with a list of values (C++11 or later) vector<int> numbers { 10, 20, 30, 40 }; // Add elements to the scores vector using push_back scores.push_back(75); // Access elements of a vector using at(i) cout << "Element at position 2: " << scores.at(2) << endl; // Determine the capacity of the scores vector int maxElements = scores.capacity(); cout << "Maximum elements a vector can store without allocating more memory: " << maxElements << endl; // Reverse the order of elements in a vector // Note: reverse() is not a member function of vector. You can reverse the vector using the reverse algorithm. reverse(scores.begin(), scores.end()); // Resize the vector to contain 5 elements, initialized to 0 scores.resize(5, 0); // Swap the contents of vec2 with scores vector<int> vec2 = {1, 2, 3}; scores.swap(vec2); // Get the size of a vector cout << scores.size() << endl; return 0; } Copy

Documents other things to note for arrays.
To access all elements in a list:
#include <iostream> array[5] = {0, 1, 2, 3, 4}; // Method 1 for (int i; i < 5; i++) { std::cout << array[i]; } // Method 2 for (int i : array) { std::cout << array[i]; } Copy
To get the number of elements in an array:
int array[3] = {0, 1, 2}; const short SIZE = sizeof(array) / sizeof(array[0]); Copy
To reassign arrays of type char:
#include <cstring> #include <string> char oldArray = "Testing"; char newArray = "New Array"; strcpy(oldArray, newArray); Copy

item.title: 08 Searching and Sorting Arrays - COP 2220
item.description:
Related:
Last modified: 2024-02-29 15:17:34



Search algorithms look for a value in an array.

Linear search: start at the beginning of an array and sequentially search all the way to the end. It will check the first value, then the second, then the third, and so on until the end of the array.
On average, it will require searches for number of elements in a list.
int linearSearch(int arr[], int size, int value) { int index = 0; // Used as a subscript to search the array int position = -1; // To record the position of search value bool found = false; // Flag to indicate if value was found while (index < size && !found) { if (arr[index] == value) // If the value is found { found = true; // Set the flag position = index; // Record the value's subscript } index++; // Go to the next element } return position; // Return the position, or -1 } Copy


Initialization: Binary search starts with the entire array and two pointers: one pointing to the beginning (left) and one pointing to the end (right) of the array.
Midpoint Calculation: It calculates the midpoint of the array by averaging the indices of the left and right pointers: mid = (left + right) / 2.
Comparison: It compares the target value with the value at the midpoint of the array.
Three Possible Outcomes:
If the target value is equal to the value at the midpoint, the search is successful, and the index of the midpoint is returned.
If the target value is less than the value at the midpoint, the search continues on the left half of the array (from left to mid - 1), excluding the midpoint.
If the target value is greater than the value at the midpoint, the search continues on the right half of the array (from mid + 1 to right), excluding the midpoint.
Iteration or Recursion: Steps 2-4 are repeated iteratively (using a loop) or recursively (calling the binary search function with updated left and right pointers) on the selected half of the array until the target value is found or the search space is empty.
Termination: If the target value is found, the index of the target is returned. If the search space is empty (i.e., left > right), the target is not present in the array, and the search terminates with a "not found" indication.
In a binary search, all the values must have an order.
On average, a binary search performs, at most, comparisons for number of elements in an array.
int binarySearch(int array[], int size, int value) { int first = 0, // First array element last = size - 1, // Last array element middle, // Mid point of search position = -1; // Position of search value bool found = false; // Flag while (!found && first <= last) { middle = (first + last) / 2; // Calculate mid point if (array[middle] == value) // If value is found at mid { found = true; position = middle; } else if (array[middle] > value) // If value is in lower half last = middle - 1; else first = middle + 1; // If value is in upper half } return position; } Copy

Sorting algorithms arrange values into a certain order.


Compare the first two elements.
If they're out of order, exchange their positions.
Else, keep moving
Move down one element. Compare the 2nd and 3rd elements. Exchange if needed. Continue until the end of the array.
Go through the array again. Make necessary exchanges.
Keep going through the array until no more exchanges are made.
Bubble sort is inefficient for large arrays.
#include <iostream> void bubbleSort(int arr[], int n) { // Flag to track if any swaps occurred in the current iteration bool swapped = true; // Outer loop iterates n-1 times to ensure each element is compared // with its neighbors for (int i = 0; i < n - 1; i++) { swapped = false; // Reset flag for each pass // Inner loop iterates n-i-1 times in each pass, as the largest i elements // are already sorted for (int j = 0; j < n - i - 1; j++) { // Compare adjacent elements if (arr[j] > arr[j + 1]) { std::swap(arr[j], arr[j + 1]); swapped = true; } } // If no swaps happened in this pass, the array is sorted correctly if (!swapped) break; } } int main() { int arr[] = {64, 34, 25, 12, 22, 11, 90}; int n = sizeof(arr) / sizeof(arr[0]); std::cout << "Unsorted array: "; for (int i = 0; i < n; ++i) std::cout << arr[i] << " "; std::cout << std::endl; bubbleSort(arr, n); std::cout << "Sorted array: "; for (int i = 0; i < n; ++i) std::cout << arr[i] << " "; std::cout << std::endl; return 0; } Copy


Locate the smallest number. Exchange it with index 0.
Locate the next smallest number. Exchange it with index 1.
Continue until all elements are arranged in order.
Selection sort is more efficient than Bubble Sort, but is more complex to understand.
#include <iostream> void selectionSort(int arr[], int n) { // Iterate through the entire array for (int i = 0; i < n - 1; i++) { // Assume the current element is the minimum int minIndex = i; // Find the actual minimum element among the remaining elements for (int j = i + 1; j < n; j++) { if (arr[j] < arr[minIndex]) { minIndex = j; } } // Swap the minimum element with the current element if (minIndex != i) { std::swap(arr[i], arr[minIndex]); } } } int main() { int arr[] = {64, 34, 25, 12, 22, 11, 90}; int n = sizeof(arr) / sizeof(arr[0]); std::cout << "Unsorted array: "; for (int i = 0; i < n; ++i) std::cout << arr[i] << " "; std::cout << std::endl; selectionSort(arr, n); std::cout << "Sorted array: "; for (int i = 0; i < n; ++i) std::cout << arr[i] << " "; std::cout << std::endl; return 0; } Copy

You can also search and sort vectors too. Only slight modifications are needed.

item.title: 09 Pointers - COP 2220
item.description:
Related:
Last modified: 2024-06-01 18:15:32



Use & to get the memory address of a variable. Related: 06 Functions - COP 2220 > 6.13 Reference Variables.
#include <iostream> int num = -99; std::cout << # // Prints address in hexadecimal Copy

Pointer variables (also called pointers) are variables that hold the address of a variable. You could say they "point" to where the data is stored.
// Defining a pointer variable // All of the definitions below do the same thing. int *pointer; int* pointer; int * pointer; // You can assign pointers to reference variables int num = 3; pointer = # // nullptr represents the address 0 int *ptr = nullptr; *ptr = num; // Store memory address of num Copy
Since pointers "point" to where the data is stored, you can indirectly modify data using pointers!
int *ptr; int num = 3; ptr = # *ptr = 4; Copy

Outputting an array name gives you the starting address of the array.
#include <iostream> using namespace std; int arr = {0, 1, 2}; cout << arr << endl; // Outputs a memory location // You can also output the first element using pointers cout << *arr << endl; // This outputs the `i`th element in arr. Subscript arithmetic int i = 1; cout << *(arr+i) << endl; cout << arr[i] << endl; // Pointers can also be used in place of array names int *ptr_arr = arr; cout << ptr_arr[0] << endl; // You can even use subscript arithmetic on pointers cout << *(ptr_arr+i) << endl; Copy
Pointer notation: uses pointers to access and manipulate data. Pointers store memory addresses, not actual data.
// Dereferencing int x = 10; int *ptr = &x; // Pointer ptr stores the address of x int value = *ptr; // Dereferencing ptr to access the value stored at the address it points to (i.e., x) Copy
Dereferencing is the process of accessing the value stored at the memory address pointed to by a pointer.

Just like before, you can use arithmetic on pointers. They work just like arithmetic on variables.

++ and -- (increments and decrements) add or subtract 1
+ and - will add and subtract
+= and -= adds or subtracts the total value on the right to the value on the left.
These operations will work on pointers and int types.
int arr[5] = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}; int *ptr = arr; // Pointer ptr points to the first element of the array int thirdElement = *(ptr + 2); // Dereferencing ptr after adding 2 to it, accessing the third element of the array Copy

Pointers are initialized just like any other variable.
int val = {0, 1, 2}; int *ptr = val; Copy
Like usual, they cannot be mixed with other data types.
Additionally, you can test for invalid addresses.

You can use comparison operators on pointers just like normal variables.
As a refresher, here they are:

>: greater than
<: less than
>=: greater than or equal to
<=: less than or equal to
!=: does not equal
==: equal to Dataview (inline field '='): Error: -- PARSING FAILED -------------------------------------------------- > 1 | = | ^ Expected one of the following: '(', 'null', boolean, date, duration, file link, list ('[1, 2, 3]'), negated field, number, object ('{ a: 1, b: 2 }'), string, variable

Pointers can be used as parameters. It will work just like a reference variable. Changes made inside a function will be kept outside of the function.
It requires:

An * in a prototype or function header
* in the body of the function
An & as an argument for the function
void swap(int *x, int *y) { int temp; temp = *x; *x = *y; *y = temp; } int num1 = 2, num2 = -3; swap(&num1, &num2); Copy
If a pointer is constant, it cannot be changed to any other address.
Constant pointers can also be pointed to constants.
int value = 22; const int * const ptr = &value; Copy

const int *: This part means that the pointer ptr points to a constant integer. This implies that you can't modify the value pointed to by ptr, but you can change the address it points to.
const: This additional const means that the pointer ptr itself is constant. Once initialized, you cannot change the address it holds; it will always point to the same memory location.

Dynamic memory lets you allocate storage for a variable while the program is running. If you do this, the computer will find an address for the allocated variable.
Use new to allocate new memory dynamically.
double *dptr = nullptr; dptr = new double; // Allocate more than one memory slot dptr = new double[100]; Copy
delete lets you free up dynamic memory. It only works if a pointer variable is initialized with new
// Dynamically allocate an array of size 3 int *arr = new int[3]; // Assign data to elements in arr arr[0] = 0; arr[1] = 1; arr[2] = 2; // Frees memory in the array delete [] arr; Copy

item.title: 01 Introduction to Statistics - STA 2023
item.description:
Data are collections of observations, like measurements, genders, or survey responses.
"Data" is plural, so it should be "data are" and not "data is."
Statistics involves planning studies, obtaining data, organizing, summarizing, presenting, analyzing, and interpreting data to draw conclusions.
A population is the complete collection of all measurements or data under consideration.
A census collects data from every member of the population.
A sample is a subcollection of members selected from a population.
voluntary response: participants choose to be in study
Steps

Prepare - goal of study? What does the data represent?
Source - Credible? reliable?
sampling method - random is best. voluntary response comple be al decide it they your to vote
Analyze
graph & explore data
apply statistical methods
Conclude is there statistical & practical significance.
Voluntary response sample: respondents choose to participate in. Can be biased
Statistical significance is not practical significance.


Parameter: measures population. Remember using population parameter
Statistic: measures sample. Remember using sample statistic
In statistics, there are two types of data:

Quantitative: numbers represent counts or measurements. This can be further divided into:
Discrete: the number of values in an interval are finite
example: number of fingers on a hand (you can have 1 finger but not have 1.1 fingers!)
Continuous: the number of values in an interval are infinite
example: weight (you can weigh 90 kg or 90.1 kg)
quantitative example: weight, height, number of fingers
Categorical: names or labels. These do not represent anything
Be careful!. It may be coded with numbers
Data can also be classified using levels of measurement. The 4 levels are:

Ratio: There is a natural zero starting point and ratios make sense
Example: height, length, volume, distance
multiplying 90 cm by 2 gives you 180 cm, which is meaningful
To test, see if you can multiply by two and if there's a 0
Interval: Differences are meaningful, but there are no natural zeros or ratios
body temperatures, shoe sizes, years
Ordinal: data is ordered, but differences can't be found or are meaningless
Rankings of colleges, grades
Measures relative, not magnitudes of differences
To tell, ask if you can subtract and still get something meaningful
Nominal: categories only. No order
eye color, sex, gender
Do not do calculations on these
Mnemonic
Nominal: name of categories
Ordinal: order of categories
Ratio: has 0s for measurement. Rati0. Ratios can also be multiplied.
Interval: no 0s for measurement
Big data: large datasets that can't be analyzed using traditional software
Data science: using stats, computer science, and software engineering to draw conclusions on data

requires background in stats, computers, and expertise in some other field
missing data for 2 reasons:
random: no reason for missing data
not at random: intentional reason for missing data
Ways to deal with missing data

Delete it (leads to bias for "missing not at random" data)
Impute (substitute) missing values

Best is randomness with placebo group

placebo: pill that does nothing
Experiment: apply some treatment and see what happens

generally better than observational studies
Good experiments use

Replication: repeating on more than one individual
Blinding: subject doesn't know if they're getting the treatment or placebo
Double-blind: Neither subjects nor experimenters know who gets placebo or treatment
Randomness: subjects assigned to groups at random. Sampling methods include:
Simple random: randomly choose participants
Systematic: choose every th sample (i.e. every 3rd, 4th, or 5th subject is tested)
Convenience: use data that is easy to get
Stratified: divide population into strata (groups). Choose randomly within each strata
Cluster: divide population into clusters (groups). Randomly select some clusters and select all members in that cluster
Mnemonic To differentiate sampling methods:
Simple random: random
Systematic: you have a system for choosing (every th time)
Convenience: pick the easiest people
Stratified: "some stratified"
Cluster: cluster = all
Confounding: when there's an effect, but we don't know what the factor is
Observational study: look at what happens, but don't do anything to affect the subjects. There are three types:

Retrospective: go back in time and collect data over some period
Cross-sectional: measure at one point in time
Prospective (aka longitudinal or cohort): measure and collect data for the future
Lurking variable: affects other variables in a study, but is not included
Sampling errors

Sampling error (aka random sampling error): selected sample deviates from true population result
Nonsampling error: human error
Nonrandom sampling error: using non-random sample (i.e. convenience sample)
Voluntary response: participants choose to participate
Designs of experiments

Completely random: randomly decide who gets treatment or placebo
Randomized block: divide subjects into groups. Decide randomly within each group who gets treatment or placebo
Example: divide men and women into groups. Decide randomly within each gender who gets treatment or placebo
Matched pairs: get measurements from same subject before and after an experiment
Proportion: portion of people who meet a certain characteristic.

This note dictates how I will write. This should be treated as a list of general rules to follow. While I strive to maintain these standards, it should be important to know that I cannot uphold these standards 100% of the time.

Keep paragraphs short. 5 sentences or shorter is ideal.
No long-winded explanations. Be concise.
List out items in a sequence often. This makes it easier to read for everyone.
AI-generated writing is fine, as long as it is clear.
Write for the sake of clarity. This means writing at the 8th grade level or lower. Do not over-complicate anything. After all, no one knows if your writing may become useful in the future.

Define complicated terms, unless those terms were already defined in the pre-requisites.
However, if pre-requisite knowledge is required, it must be stated at the beginning of the document. If the note is part of a larger series, then the introductory note to the series must state what one must know to understand the notes.
Assume that your reader is a middle schooler. For niche topics, stating required pre-requisite knowledge may not be needed if the title only appeals to a specific audience.
Example
